title: iOS app crashed by specially crafted direct message reactions

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** iOS app crashed by specially crafted direct message reactions

**Description:**
Twitter does not properly sanitize direct message reactions, making it possible for arbitrary reaction text to be shown to the user via the message preview in the direct message list. Special characters such as `\r` and `\n` are not stripped, and it is even possible to crash the app by inserting a `\0` character into the reaction text.

## Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. Start a direct message conversation with the victim (this can also be yourself).
  1. Make a request to https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json with an appropriate `conversation_id` and `dm_id` parameter, and `reaction_key` set to `\0` (an actual NUL byte).
  1. Notice that the iOS app crashes, even on any subsequent attempts to reopen it.

## Impact

This makes it trivial for an attacker to make the Twitter iOS app unusable for any user they can send a direct message to. The only recourse for the victim is to log in via twitter.com and delete the affected message or conversation.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary: iOS app crashed by specially crafted direct message reactions

Description:
Twitter does not properly sanitize direct message reactions, making it possible for arbitrary reaction text to be shown to the user via the message preview in the direct message list. Special characters such as \r and \n are not stripped, and it is even possible to crash the app by inserting a \0 character into the reaction text.

Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. Start a direct message conversation with the victim (this can also be yourself).
  2. Make a request to https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json with an appropriate conversation_id and dm_id parameter, and reaction_key set to \0 (an actual NUL byte).
  3. Notice that the iOS app crashes, even on any subsequent attempts to reopen it.

Impact

This makes it trivial for an attacker to make the Twitter iOS app unusable for any user they can send a direct message to. The only recourse for the victim is to log in via twitter.com and delete the affected message or conversation.

activities.message: Actually, the NUL byte wasn't being sent in my test, that isn't the problem. Simply an empty value for `reaction_key` also causes the crash.
activities.markdown_message: Actually, the NUL byte wasn't being sent in my test, that isn't the problem. Simply an empty value for reaction_key also causes the crash.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @nyuszika7h,

When we tested this behavior we could not find the `reaction_key` parameter you mentioned in your report. Can you provide us a bit more information about your tests so we can understand how to reproduce your request to `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json`.  What specific action did you perform to trigger a request to `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json`? Can you trigger this request on Twitter's Desktop site or can it only be triggered using a mobile app, Tweetdeck, or another Twitter platform? A video explaining what you are seeing can also greatly help us to evaluate your report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security

Can you trigger this request on Twitter's Desktop site or can it only be triggered using a mobile app, Tweetdeck, or another Twitter platform? A video explaining what you are seeing can also greatly help us to evaluate your report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security

activities.message:
I modified the request from the new twitter.com (Twitter Web App):

```
curl -i 'https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json?reaction_key=&conversation_id=[CONV_ID]&dm_id=[DM_ID]' -X POST -H 'x-csrf-token: [CSRF_TOKEN] -H 'authorization: Bearer AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAANRILgAAAAAAnNwIzUejRCOuH5E6I8xnZz4puTs%3D1Zv7ttfk8LF81IUq16cHjhLTvJu4FA33AGWWjCpTnA' -H 'cookie: auth_token=[AUTH_TOKEN]; ct0=[CSRF_TOKEN]'
```
activities.markdown_message:
I modified the request from the new twitter.com (Twitter Web App):

curl -i 'https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json?reaction_key=&conversation_id=[CONV_ID]&dm_id=[DM_ID]' -X POST -H 'x-csrf-token: [CSRF_TOKEN] -H 'authorization: Bearer AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAANRILgAAAAAAnNwIzUejRCOuH5E6I8xnZz4puTs%3D1Zv7ttfk8LF81IUq16cHjhLTvJu4FA33AGWWjCpTnA' -H 'cookie: auth_token=[AUTH_TOKEN]; ct0=[CSRF_TOKEN]'

activities.message:
Thank you for your follow-up @nyuszika7h,

We attempted to use the Curl command included in your report, but this command triggered the following error.
`{"errors":[{"code":38,"message":"id parameter is missing."}]}`. In order to test this behavior, we copied the parameters used in a typical Direct Message request (e.g. `api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/new.json`) and added it to this Curl command. Most of these parameters were identical except for the  `dm_id` parameter which we replaced with the `request_id` parameter in `api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/new.json` request.

Did you use this Curl command in your tests? If so, can you provide us a video that demonstrates how you were able to avoid this "missing ID parameter" error?  In addition, if it is at all possible to tell us how you triggered the  outgoing request `https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json`, it would greatly help us address this behavior.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your follow-up @nyuszika7h,

We attempted to use the Curl command included in your report, but this command triggered the following error.
{"errors":[{"code":38,"message":"id parameter is missing."}]}. In order to test this behavior, we copied the parameters used in a typical Direct Message request (e.g. api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/new.json) and added it to this Curl command. Most of these parameters were identical except for the dm_id parameter which we replaced with the request_id parameter in api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/new.json request.

Did you use this Curl command in your tests? If so, can you provide us a video that demonstrates how you were able to avoid this "missing ID parameter" error? In addition, if it is at all possible to tell us how you triggered the outgoing request https://api.twitter.com/1.1/dm/reaction/new.json, it would greatly help us address this behavior.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
I'm using the new DM reactions feature. Here are the full steps to reproduce:

1. Go to twitter.com in Chrome
1. Open network inspector (F12 -> Network)
1. Open a random DM conversation
1. Hover over one of the messages
1. Click the little heart with a plus icon
1. Click any of the reaction emojis
1. Right click on the second `new.json` request (the POST one, not OPTIONS)
1. Copy -> Copy as cURL (bash)
1. Paste the command into a bash shell, and change the parameter (e.g. `reaction_key=funny`) to `reaction_key=`. (In my example above, I removed some of the unnecessary headers/options, but they can be left there.)
1. Open the DM list in the iOS app. This should crash the app, at least if the reaction is the latest message in the conversation.

Attached full POC video. (Ignore the Dev Tools crash, not sure why that happens but it's not relevant to this report.)
activities.markdown_message:
I'm using the new DM reactions feature. Here are the full steps to reproduce:

  1. Go to twitter.com in Chrome
  2. Open network inspector (F12 -> Network)
  3. Open a random DM conversation
  4. Hover over one of the messages
  5. Click the little heart with a plus icon
  6. Click any of the reaction emojis
  7. Right click on the second new.json request (the POST one, not OPTIONS)
  8. Copy -> Copy as cURL (bash)
  9. Paste the command into a bash shell, and change the parameter (e.g. reaction_key=funny) to reaction_key=. (In my example above, I removed some of the unnecessary headers/options, but they can be left there.)
  10. Open the DM list in the iOS app. This should crash the app, at least if the reaction is the latest message in the conversation.

Attached full POC video. (Ignore the Dev Tools crash, not sure why that happens but it's not relevant to this report.)

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
